The game catch my eye by the art and surprisingly it's free. Eternal Senia is an RPG Maker style game with unique battle system but simple with a story about swordman girl Senia who find her lost sister a priest Magaleta in to the 'Tower of Eternity'.  Tower of Eternity, a mysterious dungeon with a powerful power call 'Eternity' that can grant a wish if someone receive and grant control it, many have tried but all failed and never come back. Why Magaleta seek for a such power?   Ok, enough with the story. let's start with Cons.   Cons - Not long enough, about 6-7 Hrs with some grind. - Translation isn't perfect, there are a lot of an awkward grammar once a while through the game, need to improve for more experience with story. - Can make you cry.   Pros - Great battle system but simple unique and cool, an ARPG style without fightscene and not like a cheap RPG Maker game you can find on internet. You'll find yourself addict to it. - Deep story and great development of story line that make you forget the time. - OST is great especially piano, love it! - Interesting Characters. - Crafting system is simple and easy to grind but effective. - Multiple difficulty on boss fight, hardmode is fun and challenge just take your time read the mechanic and you'll be fine. (Not effect the story) - Can change resolution with less quality lost.(F6) - Some Ragnarok reference make you feel nostalgic - Multiple ending. - FREE!  There's no reason not to try this game.  10/10 would keep on finding again.
Choose your own bad end for free.

Eternal Senia takes you on an epic journey through the eyes of a young girl named Senia. Although simple in presentation, this game exemplifies how the ARPG genre should be through innovative changes to classic mechanics and a strong focus on story and ambiance.   The graphical style and user input are sure to inspire feelings of nostalgia for gamers over 30. A throw back to a time when fundamental game play mattered more than death counters or clicks per second, Eternal Senia is a fresh new experience that anyone looking for a little bit of relaxing fun at any age should be able to pick up and enjoy.   This game has:     immersive atmospheric effects and high quality background music     replayability due to sections of randomly generated content and multiple endings     side quests for collectables and optional boss monsters  Game developer and publisher Holy Priest has delivered a gift in the form of Eternal Senia, completely free of charge, back to the game-playing community that embraced him many years ago within Ragnarok Online. I have no doubt that others who take the time to experience this labor of love will be similarly motivated by his inspirational work.  In the end, the game is shorter than I would like. I also would have preferred more graphics options including native support for 16:9 displays and the ability to play in a windowed fullscreen mode, however these are minor technical points compared to the positive aspects of the game. For what is essentially a hobbyist project, Eternal Senia is an unqualified success worth taking note of.  9/10

It's a solid retro RPG with very high production values, from art to music to game mechanics.  Is a diamond in the rough, a nostalgic throwback RPG. I thoroughly enjoy playing this 16-bit adventure and strongly recommend it to any true RPG fan.  Like the 16-bit graphics and anime-styled artwork, the sounds and music of this game help add to that classic RPG feeling. None of these things will leave a big impression on you, but they are good for a game like this. The controls are simple. There is also the option to play in either full-screen or window mode.   The Good: + Good graphics and sound for a 16-bit game + Low CPU usage - runs smoothly on most all systems + Full Controller Support  The Bad: - With tons of dialogue, an auto-scroll timer would be a welcome addition   True RPG fans will want to add this game to their libraries.

This game is really lovely and well made. Would give 9/10  Story:  It starts when a young swordswoman called Senia tries to find her High Priestess Sister Magaleta, which vanished into the Tower of Eternity. Following her, you get to know more about the sad background story and emotional relationship between those two.  Gameplay:  This game is doable included all endings and doing all sidequest in about 4-5 hours. It's short but still a lot of fun and once you are into it, you don't really want to stop playing it. As you can see it's an ARPG, so you are basically only playing one character with some skills equipped. A good thing is that you can grind ingredients and craft your own equipment in the game.  Difficulty:  To be honest killing the small mob is really easy it's like u get 0 damage from the mini monsters, only the boss fights are challenging and only on Hard Mode anyway.  Characters:  Really well done, I like the art design and also the personalities of all characters. (might be that I known them from Ragnarok Online, which was my favourite MMO 7 years along)  Music: Not many different tracks, however some of them are tearjerkers and very emotional, which totally fits perfectly at specific scenes.  It's not the best game I've played, but a real good one.  I'd definitely redcommend it.

What's that you say? A free game you say? A free game with a good amount of content in it? A GOOD free game? Sign me up!   First of all, the story. It's good. Not great, but good. Definetly had me engaged, desperate to see the final outcome. It took me a while to get all three endings but the good news is you don't have to play through the entire game again just to see a different ending. Characters are an important part of any good story and Eternal Senia has some ok characters. You get a decent idea of Senia and Magaleta's personalitys and their backstories which really helped add extra emotional impact to the endings (There are three endings and all of them are real tear jerkers). That being said, they didn't feel quiet as fleshed out as they could have been.  Gameplay in Eternal Senia is really good. Combat is quiet a bit different from the usual RPG affair with no turn based combat or anything like that. Instead you simply run into enemies to attack them and use Q, W, E and R to use special attacks. It's a simple system that works very well with the game. The graphics are also nice and I really liked the artstyle. The music was also really great. Not much else to really say there. Um. Yeah. So it's pretty great. And free. Not flawless though, it's a tad repetitive right at the end and the final boss fight was a bit unfair, it's still a good game.   +Reasonable characters +Decent story +Very nice visuals +Great music +Simple yet good gameplay  -Characters could have been a little more fleshed out -A tiny bit repetitive towards the end -Could have done with at least one happy ending  70/100 - 'Just a lil' bit 2 sad'   Sequel please? Pleeeeeeeeeeeeeeeaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaase? Pls?

Arguably one of the better ARPGs on Steam. Reasons:  Story: The story is quite solid. A remarkable journey where the sister ventures into danger to find the only family she has left, her sister and will risk anything no matter how small the chances are, to be with her and to back to the Church together. Throughout the Journey Senia is more and more emotional yet never gives up. Determination at it's finest. 10/10  Gameplay: Simplistic and yet fun. Maybe not the best combat system but it's still one fun game to play. The Game developer didn't try to win us over with the gameplay regardless. We're in it for the story. Even thuogh so the traps, monsters and obstacles to push are fun and joyable in it's own right. 9/10  Grahpics/Visuals: I can tell they worked hard on it. The characters look absolutely stunning. They display the correct emotions at the correct time. The visuals also impact how we,the player feel about thie story and we feel more emerged into the story, Feeling Senia's pain. 9/10  Music(OST): I'll be honest here and say this game's OSTs are some of the best OST's I've ever heard. Especially the menu music. QUite addicting, it's like a mix of rap and hiphop. Anyway the game developers did a good job designing the music. It fits well into the game and they put it in the right times for a better emotional attachment to both the character and the story. 10/10  Overall Rating for Eternal Senia: 9.5/10. It's without a doubt my top RPG at the moment and I hope they'll make a sequel. This game must be explored by other gamers out there who's not looking for anything super fancy, but a nice little RPG that can take your heart away.

From what may seem a simple game with a easy fighting system at first slowly takes you with its beautiful soundtrack and artstyle. For an indie game, this one is worth trying out. It won't take you too long to beat it, and it's pretty enjoyable on its way through. It can provide suprisingly diffcult boss fights when need be. The best comparison of this game for me would be The Witch's House, Mad Father, and Ib. Even though these are horror games, they have the same rpg elemets, great soundtracks, and my personal favorite multiple endings that aren't afraid to go a bit deeper. Overall I loved this game and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did. P.S it's FREE ^_^

This game is FREE.    And it's better than many games I've payed sizeable amounts of money for.   You heard right. This is a totally free game, so unless you hate video games you probably should give it a quick download and at least check it out.  Now that that's out of the way.. yes, indeed, it's an RPGmaker game-- but don't let that turn you away. Sure, it's got RPGmaker assets for most the backgrounds/terrain and some of the enemies, but;   - It's got fully custom character art for the main characters, with many different states as well as gorgeous full-screen art for many cutscenes;  - It's got REALLY nice custom music with only, like, 2 of the 20 or so songs in the game being anything approaching repetitive or grating, and several tracks being downright excellent;  - It's got a simple but beautiful and bittersweet story, especially once you get to the end;  - And best of all, it's got a hand-crafted action-RPG battle system reminiscent of the original Ys games and other oldschool RPGs instead of your regular random-battles-turn-based RPGmaker faire.  My only real complaint would be its length; as a free game made almost entirely by one guy, I wasn't expecting too much, but this lovely game is simply over far too quickly. Even if you're the type like me that's going to go way out of your way to do absolutely every single optional thing possible and grind every item, you're still looking at a single afternoon's work all told. The good news is the guy's apparently already hard at work on a sequel.  So yes, get this game, download it, play it, fill out the post-game survey, let the creator know he's a rad dude, and have a great time. Sure, the gameplay's quite simple overall, it's not very long, and there are some generic graphical assets you MIGHT notice in between the gorgeous manga-style character art, but I can think of little excuse for anyone not to give this game a play.

While most reviews focus on the emotion aspect of the game, I can tell you that besides the story, the gameplay is actually quite fun. Don't let the first few minutes of combat turn you down - you would be very surprised how challenging boss fights can be (at least on hard mode). They are definitely not bump into them until one with less hp dies.  In short: - Good story - Memorable (although, not entirely original) characters - Challenging boss fights - Excellent music and fantastic art design  There are some down points as well, but do not take much from the game and are usually minor. Such as enemies before bosses serve mostly as moving obstacles and experience boosts; you can't craft from items that are equipped; some visual cues seem a bit off. But all in all, nothing that messes with you gameplay experience by much.

- SPOILER ALERT -    Right, I'm going to say my review about the game up-top first then to whomever is interested, there's a short? trivia right after the review~ Here we go :>   GAMEPLAY I have played and completed the game in within 4.6 hrs, hard mode with everything unlocked except from endings #1 and 3. The game is so simple and straightforward, heck, there are puzzles where hints are discreetly hiding right in front of your face to which I find quite enjoyable for an ARPG~  Visual design and Music I must say that I'll give the developer a double thumbs up if he drew all of these by himself! If he only had more time and people to help him, this game could have been more for an SNES-like game. As for the music, I am hearing a lot of familiar BGMs and OSTs from anime, it must've been remixed version? Correct me if I'm wrong but one of the bgms in the game is strikingly similar to one of Clannad's BGM but overall, each of them perfectly fits to where they are placed.  Do I recommend the game? If you're a Ragnarok Online player,  YES  due to an ample amount of reasons. What if you're not? I still recommend it trying, first of all, it's FREE. A game which you could play for approximately 5 hours and has 3 endings for you to unlock if the game managed to reel you in.  A truly enjoyable game~    FUN TRIVIA   ALRIGHTY! As the developer says front-hand without sugar coating it whatelse, etc etc. This game is inspired by one of the best MMORPG back in the old days called Ragnarok Online which is also based from the manwha of the same name by Lee Myung jin.   History, comparison and differences;   The developer also stated that Egnigem Cenia or Ygnizem Seniar from RO (or whatever her name is on your preferred language) and Senia of the game  are identical to both name and appearance only  as the Egnigem Cenia from RO met far worst/cruel/fatal fate than our Senia here which RO players must not link it from the original in any of sort.  Before I continue, I've only seen the 2nd ending of this game. I don't have the time to play it again #, also completed it at hard mode lvl 34, all unlockables, get!    A fate worst than death;    Egnigem Cenia   She is the boss of Biolab 2nd floor and is revealed and confirmed to be Seyren Windsor's little sister; their father resisted the human experimentation thus as a punishment, the Rekenber Corporation experimented on them as per shown in Biolab questline. After she and countless others died due to an explosion where the corporation attempted to do its final experimentations whereas they resisted to give in which made the containment area to overload. Their spirits materialized into the present world ever haunting the place to which whomever tries to stumble upon the dreadful place will meet their demise.   Ygnizem Senia   The only survivor from a monster invasion occured on her village which later then she was saved by the Archbishop Malgaleta. Ventured through the Tower of Eternity to look for the person whom she cherishes the most only to find that 'Eternity' has already taken control of the said person. Our heroine has the capability of containing Eternity within herself which we don't know if has fatal side effects but as shown in the game, it's more like she becomes the vessel once she absorbs Eternity and so indeed what happened. Our heroine, Senia, mercilessly slashed Malgaleta to death whilst trying her best to save her but it was all for naught. At the end, both of them perished, Senia, wasn't able to contain Eternity vanishes? along with them giving the game a bittersweet ending.   NOW THEN, isn't that quite a fun trivia?

After just under an hour of playing, I'm afraid I couldn't take 'Eternal Senia' any more.  An interesting, yet incomprehensible game with characters and plot that feel like they were cut out from cardboard, game design more backhanded than a Rakshasa and all put to the most baffling musical scoring I have ever encountered.  The game's writing is full of contrivances, grammatical errors and scenes that are either unneccessary or perhaps just a little bit too long.   I remember a key instance where an elf showed up in my path, armed with a bow and arrow. Immediately I saw that the bridge I was stood on was wide enough to sidestep their attack, and that they had a missile nocked and ready to fire, but the game decided that Senia hadn't fulfilled her moping quota yet and needed to strain out a tutorial disguised as poor character development, instead of me just knocking the forest dweller onto his silken britches.  The gameplay is fundementally flawed, if at times entirely broken. The key to interaction here seems to be a unique, action-oriented combat system in which mobile foes wander around aimlessly on a grid, until you walk up to them in order to initiate an auto-attack, slicing them to peices with your sword. However, attacking has a high chance to knock you back one space (Though not into hazards like trips and traps, because that would be engaging), and very quickly it devolves into 'Butt Heads with Creepy Mc. Crawly #394 encounting'.  Bosses tend to shake things up a bit more than regular grunts, with actual attack patterns that force you to move around the arena instead of just bumping into them repeatedly, but they're all far too easy and exploitable to see the full potential of this system. The first boss in particular, was a dragon with a mighty breath weapon... and an arthritic neck. I slew him easily by moving up to his left flank and carving it into wyrm-burgers.  There are also puzzles - which are nearly all beatable from brute force - traps that pose little to no threat when your Hit Points regenerates faster than lightning and a crafting system that aims to releive frustration, but this is mitigated by the overly fast pace and the fact that a girl I found in a magical forest, deep within a ethereal kingdom of swords and sorcery knows what 'Facebook' is.
Could have been a lot better. But it's free so I can't complain too much.

This is a fine game but it is overrated. Based on the overwhelmingly positive reviews I was expecting a masterpiece. The game mechanics are simple but at times can be fun. The story is basic and not nearly as amazing as the positive reviews led me to believe. The character designs are very beautiful and the music is good.   The main reason I give it a thumbs down is due to the lack of polish in the user interface. You start the game and there is nothing telling you what keys to use to move or even how to accept or cancel. It's very ackward for the first few minutes. There is also a bug where two types of gems show up with the same name and you are left wondering why you can't build certain items eventhough the gem is in your inventory. Some of the boss enemies sit there not doing anything. You hit them until your health goes down, then get some space, wait for health to regenerate, hit them some more, then repeat.   It's an average game given that is is free but I could have spent my time playing something better.

You might think that the central mechanic of walking your character into monsters makes the game boring.  Ironically, that isn't really the problem.  If you have ever played any of the Ys games, this is fundamentally a dumbed-down version of those games with much less dynamic moment-to-moment gameplay.  On top of that, the game was originally written in Japanese, then translated into English... and while the translation is never non-sensical, it is obvious that it was not translated by a native speaker.  But even beyond that... the story just isn't very interesting at all. You're a girl who has lost her sister. You need to go find her. You run into... some people along the way. None of them are very interesting or memorable, nor is the protagonist, for that matter. There is just nothing gripping about the story of this game.  Given the very simplistic, not very rewarding gameplay and the unrewarding story, there is just no reason to play this game. It isn't terrible, but lots of things aren't terrible; for something to be worth your time, it should be actively good.  This is not.  Your time is better spent doing other things. Read a book instead; it will be much more fulfilling. Or play a better game.

Eternal Senia is an old school sprite art ARPG. The gameplay is fairly basic with you moving into enemies to attack them. What carried the game for me was the story and the art design. The areas are really nicely designed and I loved the sprite art for the character.  The dev took a lot of inspiration from the mmo Ragnarok Online. I spent years playing RO so it was a big positive for me. Overall I loved the game and I hope the dev keeps making games.  Pros Great story Art style is amazing The game is Free! Simple gamplay that even someone new or not skilled at games can enjoy. I loved the sound track. On the shorter end. It took me about 4 hours to beat the game without finding all the chests. A shorter experience is best for this game i think. Lets the game tell its story without dragging on.  Cons. I think the biggest downside for me was that i wished the crafting was a little bit more diverse. It got a bit repetive moving to a new area and having to collect a new type of crystal + cloth. Just a small gripe though.  Overall I think the game is great. Definitely worth playing. Especially considering its Free!

I don't usually write reviews, but this game deserves one  Let's start from the beginning:   This game is by no means beautiful, nor is it very long (took me around 4h to finish it), it doesn't mean it's bad, on the contrary, there's a lot of cutscenes (dialogs fits more the bill).  The combat system is pretty simple and easy to use. It feels a bit like playing the early type of Zelda, where you go from one screen to another, hitting monsters, gathering ressources to upgrade your gear, there's a total of 4 skills you can use to make the battle easier. As a fan of JRPG's music, the soundtrack in this game is AMAZING.  Now, there's one downside to this game: the ending(s). I'll let you guys see it for yourselves.  There's a few grammar problems here and there, the game was originally made in Chinese, I'm guessing the translation was not by a professional but it's not important in this case, that's a minor thing. Feel free to try this game, it's finishable in a few hours, and it costs 0$.   TL,DR: it feels like playing Zelda (the ones on SNES or gameboy), good music, the game costs nothing, go try and don't cry on the ending(s)

This is quite a fun game with an awesome premise. Senia is looking for her sister (a nun) Magaleta, and is trying to overcome so many things. From her own fears and insecurities from when Magaleta rescued her from monsters as a child to when Magaleta disappears and she has to be strong to find her and fend for herself. Senia displays interesting emotions, and being brave is beautifully shown. I did like the part where she has to get the two-handed sword from a woman who died and has to steel up the resolve to fight the dragon. Weapons/armor breaking resembling plot points is quite unique too.  The game is free, so there's nothing to lose for trying even if you prefer the action to not be so automated (you exchange shots bumping into enemies but there is some strategy involved with location).

That would've been satisfying. I even went through and got all of the bonuses and stuff just in case that had anything to do with it, but no. The endings got worse after I got the pendant back. We could've just had an awesome 'thanks for all your hard work to get the game completed 100%, so here's your awesome sister back with no strings attached', but instead you have to tug my heartstrings. ♥♥♥♥! That almost made me hit the button to not recommend the game because I really wanted a happy ending, but I guess if you want to cover your keyboard in tears pathetically with your folks in the other room wondering how pixels turn into sadness, I guess this game is for you.     All that being said, I did really enjoy the game. what's nice is that if you want to go through all of the levels and find all of the stuff in the game, you don't have to grind a ton because you grind while you're searching. That way you don't have to feel like you're going through tropes just to progress forward. The combat is also pretty nice because it's simple, doesn't require a ton of learning and feels nice. For a free rpg maker game, the design of the gameplay is what I would've expected from a great Super Nintendo classic. Good job. Now go tug someone else's heart strings turd...

First of all: IT'S FREE!  A couple of years ago, I played a little free game called King Story. It was an unfinished game, the first in a series, but it's combat system was pretty neat. Like in Eternal Senia, you attack by charging into the enemy. Even if it is more limited due to RPG Maker mechanics, it was really cool to see this concept again - one that I really missed from the first game, that let me longing for a sequel that will never come out.  The character design was incredible. I am not familiar with RPG Maker so I do not know if all the sprites are original from the creator (they too are superb btw), but the drawings for the protagonists and bosses were wonderful for a free game, better than a lot of paid games with anime visuals. The story was great, it is simple but manage to immerse you into the plot, and actually like the characters.  What really got into me was the secret chamber - don't read if you want to discover for yourself. Until then, it was a really good game that I pretty much enjoyed and became attached to the characters; but to see the love invested in this game, and the care the developer devoted to it really moved me. The reference to old games, specially Legend of Mana, made it something special. It was like it could be any of us there, determined to create a game moved by childhood memories, and sharing with people that could possibly get the same feeling. Maybe I am reading too much between the lines, but this line of thought amuses me, and make the fact that it's free even more interesting. I don't know, I give it some thought and this game may as well figure between my favorite games.  The only thing that I quite not liked was the soundtrack. It is not bad, really, but it's just not my thing and it seemed a bit off sometimes. And after some point it became a bitty grindy, and I found myself yearning for the the progress of the story rather than having fun with the combat. Nothing sort of a nuisance though. I am seeking out for the dev next game, if it is expected.

For a short game, literally got all 3 endings in about 6 hours, it was absolutely gorgeous. It was by far one of the best, actually the best, RPG Maker game I've played so far. I will put specifics below.  Story: One of the three biggest things that made this short game amazing and memorable. The story of the main character risking her life to save her older sister is maybe a cliche to an extent, but they got that cliche and made it beautiful. The story has 3 endings total, each one being emotional and memorable. This is one of those select few were I actually loved all the alternate endings. Personally speaking though, the 3rd ending is the best. 8/10 for the story (could easily be 10 if it wasn't only 6hrs long)  Graphics: The second biggest thing that made me love this game. Anyone who played Visual Novels willl more than likely see what I mean when I say these graphics are absolutely amazing. This game has some of the best graphics I've ever seen in RPG Maker games, competing with a lot of Visual Novels. Of course, the gameplay graphic is mediocre, but you can't expect much from RPG Maker in that aspect. (Still amazing for being made in RPG Maker). It's the story images that hit me hard. They were the biggest thing that made me love this game. 9/10 for the graphics  Music: This is definetly important in games. What background to play at what time? Should it be silent? Loud or quite? Fast or slow? Well, this game did an amazing job with the soundtrack. I am using the piano theme on my phone for a ringtone as I type this, and I am loving it. The soundtrack was beautifuly done, adding a lot of emotion to the story and images. 9/10 (the music was beautiful, but a few played several times throughout making it not quite a 10)  Gameplay: The gameplay was interesting in several ways. The creator got rid of the turn-base combat and instead implemented his own. You move around freely and attack enemies by running into them. You also us the buttons 'Q'W'E'R' to use your skills. It sounds sort of simple, which it is, but the enemies make it challenging. Especially the bosses, who have unique skills of their own and can do AOEs causing major damage. I've died by all the main bosses except 2, the first boss (Slime) and the semi-final boss (Final if you get Ending 1). 7.5/10 (feel like more could be added)  Overall, I give the game a 8.5/10. It had a great story combined with both great graphics and music. The controls were simple, yet amazing in their own way. I would most definitely reccomend this FREE game to anyone who loves RPGs and Visual Novels. I would've proudly paid for it if it costed money. =(^,.,^)=  Nominated for the 'I'm not crying' reward. =(^,.,^)=

Eternal Senia...well, it's a free game, so trying it out is probably the best option regardless of what reviews say.  But for me, well, I had fun with the game. I thought it was definitely worth the few hours I put into it, and I admire the developer's dedication and thought put into the game (the crafting system is a good example, being easy to follow while still adding flavor). The soundtrack has its fair share of standout moments, too (personal favorites include 'Inner Forest' and 'Passage of Bravery'). A few minor issues exist here and there (e.g. iffy translations from Chinese, lack of exit game option), but nothing major.  What keeps me from showering this game with praise, though, is that I could never get into the story, or its characters. A quick glance at the reviews suggests that I'm in the minority here, but for me, the story felt unoriginal and uninspiring to the fullest, never deviating from the tired 'love conquers all' theme, never even trying to explore minor intricacies like the mysterious 'Eternity' substance.  So, ultimately, I end up viewing this game as the developer's tribute to eastern RPGs - a soft, quick encapsulation of the genre, but nothing of substance on its own. Do I recommend it? For free, it'd be hard not to. But neither do I think you're missing out if you don't bother.

Here I am Writing a review on the Free To Play game 'Eternal Senia'. Well first off im just gonna say how I felt going thru this game. - I enjoyed it, the story was solid and left me crying in the end. The art was pretty damn good in my opinion. The Characters were very cute and the story between them very nice. The Combat was pretty good being it was made with RPG maker. The enemies were plentiful and they dropped items which were crafting supplies used to make. Armor and weapons. The crafting system was very grindy but that just made me want to put even more time into it. For it being a Chineese/Japanese game the english translation was pretty decent. I found myself pretty happy thru the entirety of the game. Until I played all 3 endings, I bawled at the end of them but I loved all of them as each ending showed how each character felt and showed how the relationship had evolved between the characters. The sound track is Phenominal to be quite frank and if you think its not you have some issues. The level design was very odd but interesting and I often went back to see if I left anything behind me.   Im not going to give this game a number rating, but instead im just going to say. If you loved Anime, and enjoy story and dont give a ♥♥♥♥ about graphics and want a nice dungeon crawler esc. feel to a game. This game is for you and look no further, so quit reading this review and get the damn game and experience the ♥♥♥♥ing beauty of this game.  -Gabe Carter

There are stories where the world is at risk, and the hero must rise up to fight injustice and restore balance to the world. Eternal Senia is not that kind of story.  Despite the first impression the name might give, the game is very short (My [at time of writing] 5.2 hours of playtime was enough to see everything.), but that does not mean it is not also good. I won't go into detail of the story because, since it is so short, just about everything falls under spoiler territory.   The mechanics are very intuitive and easy to get used to. As this is an ARPG, there is no need for navigating battle menus for each time you bump into one of the random mobs wandering around; the player will damage the enemy by simply walking into them. Additionally, there are no random encounters in this game, so the player is free to completely ignore the mobs about 75% of the time. The remaining 25% is when they are blocking the one way forward. Grinding is almost totally unneeded, and simple normal progression will generally keep the player's level and skills high enough to overcome whatever comes their way. Boss battles are done in an interesting way; with the exception of the first and penultimate, they are a static part of the background and the player has to run into one tile where they are vulnerable, while dodging AoE attacks and summoned mobs.  The heroine is developed rather well, as she narrates the backstory between chapters. She also stands out from many RPG heroes by not being chosen by any divine entity or having been predestined to go on a journey; she is just a regular person that knows how to use a sword and has an objective.  Lastly, there are a total of three endings to this game, based on player actions, which can roughly be seen as a bad, normal, and true ending. The game prompts the player to save in the endgame every time they are about to reach a decision gate for determining which ending they get. Because of this, replaying the whole game is not needed to see all the endings.   In the end, this is a good game with an engaging story despite its brevity, and certainly an afternoon could be spared in order to experience this. Word of advice, be ready to cry at the endings.

I spent around five hours with this game, debating whether I'm impressed or sad.  The visuals are very simple but there's a lot of care and attention into making every screen make sense. The characters can look a little out of place sometimes, as there are a few sprites here and there which were probably used from the default models from RPGMaker and they don't really go well with the handmade models. The two main characters are also extremely obviously based off of a female Swordsman and a female High Priest, both from the Ragnarok Online MMORPG. I wish the creator would have put a little more work into making them look more unique, because it truly is very obvious. That said, the hand-drawn portraits and models look nice.  Every level is carefully designed with its share of unique challenges, from exploding enemies to platforming. It's genuinely impressive how much love was put into each and every segment of the game world -- even being a linear game, there's a lot of incentive to truly explore and gather materials, as well as tackle the secret levels for special rewards.   The combat system is very reminiscent of the Ys series; this game wears its inspirations on its sleeve but I believe that's a good thing. It's relaxing but, at the same time, it can be quite challenging to overcome certain bosses even though there's not even an attack button. The skill system isn't as fleshed out as it could be and using SP to increase the skills is very simplistic -- most of the time, you'll just want to dump the points in all skills equally but only a couple are really ever truly useful (at least up until where I am). Even still, each skill has its very own application and they stand out from each other.  The story is extremely generic but it keeps itself mysterious enough that it doesn't need to shove itself down your throat. I believe this was the right decision. The narrative wouldn't be interesting enough to flesh out every 30 minutes with exposition so the choice to keep it to a sheer minimum and focus instead on Senia's confusion was appropriate. It's a little weird that all bosses (up until where I am) are basically variations of a succubus but that's not a real complaint or anything. Just something that annoyed me a little bit. I'd also like to point out that the game's text sometimes suffers from a severe lack of proof-reading by a fluent English speaker. There are a LOT of grammar mistakes and even some conveyance problems, particularly in dialogue. It's too bad because it harms the already very vanilla storyline. It's an issue that's easily fixed. It may add to the charm for some players but, in my case, it's a little cringy at times.  I noted at the start that I didn't know whether to be impressed or sad. This is because, on one hand, I'm impressed at the amount of sheer love the creator put into making this game. Most complaints I noted above could be justified by the fact that the game was made on absolutely no budget and it's being distributed for free. I'm sad, however, because this is one of those games which will find it very hard to get publicized due to its nonexistent marketing campaign and minimalistic approach.  As an indie game, this is clearly a step behind a lot of videogames as far as technology goes. As a labour of love, being distributed at absolutely no cost, with no DLC or any strings attached, this deserves my utmost respect and admiration.  This is free. Download it. Play it proudly. Now.

An easy-going JRPG with a heavy focus on the narrative.  The battle system is simplistic, but unique for an RPG-Maker title. Took me 12 hours to 100% the game and view all the available endings. The last 3 hours were full of grind, but if you are planning on taking down the Final Boss on Hard Mode then it is absolutely necessary. If you're going straightfoward, then you will find that you can get away with a lower level and still get through things okay.   The true ending was the most enjoyable to me, and leaves a somewhat cliffhanger to a sequel. The game definitely has a lot of heart and the art direction is stunning.

I loved the game graphics, gameplay, music and storyline! The game is way too easy even when you do the bosses on hard.  I've beaten the game 100 % getting everything I could!  --General  Graphics are the usual type made half 3D. Sadly bosses lack any sort of animation, which is fixed by adding interesting attacks (lasers seem to be quite popular!)  Gameplay is simple and addicting. You have few skills to use, but main fighting goes by simply walking into the enemies to cause damage. Leveling up really feels like you get a lot stronger, and though upgrading your gear is slightly grindy, it's still decently fast and with this fighting style it's also a bit of fun.  Music.. Cant say much about it, it was good enough for me and my friend to pretty much sing along with it, by reading the texts aloud in the music rhytm :)  Story in the game is good and involving, nothing epic, on the contrary it could be the story of an average family, with some monsters and magic mixed up with, making it more believable and much better than your usual plotlines. And the ending.. I loved it! It breaks the usual ending format slightly as well with a twist.  Also checking out the Dev-room was a nice extra to see inside the effort put into making the game.  --Negatives  On the other side, the bosses lacked animation and at some points that felt out of place compared to the rest of the feel in the game. I guess bosses need to look different after all. Even though the bossfights were fun and all, if they had atleast moved a few pixels up and down hovering it would've been better in my opinion, to make them look alive instead of paintings. Developers did explain the reason for this in the Dev-room.  The game was also really easy most of the time, while the bosses were challenging on hardmode and seemed to require some extra care. If only the normal enemies midgame onwards would've required slightly more to beat as well. Now I know this game must've been hard for some people, but since the bosses had hardmode, I would've loved to play hardmode even outside bossfights.  --Overall  I loved every moment of this game and definetly would recommend it to other people! It's also free so even if you dont know the genre this is a good game to try get in on!  For the developers: Good job! I will eagerly wait and hope for more games from you!  9/10

This game is fantastic!! When first starting the game you're greeted with some of the best menu music I've ever heard. You're thrown into a basic tutorial dungeon right away, and the story is then explained by flashbacks. I currently haven't beaten the game yet, but the story is great and I won't be spoiling any of it here. At first I thought the combat was choppy, which it is because it's using RPG Maker's (VX Ace or XP I'm not sure, most likely XP) tile system for movement which means you can do a dash attack and go through an enemy because technically he's in a transitionary limbo. However after the first boss in the tutorial and after fighting medusa, I realized that the combat is actually really good. Overall I'd say the combat is pretty much like a top down Zelda game. Next I'd have to say the UI is really good looking and custom made, so is character art. There's a neat skill system and it always makes me feel as if I'm progressing which helps things to flow and stay interesting. In conclusion I'd say this game is amazing especially since it's free. My only complaint would be the heavy reliance on RPG Maker's default assets. So finally, I'd give this game a 9/10  Pros ------------------------- - Awesome music - Smooth combat - Good story - Good art - Pretty UI - It's free -------------------------  Cons ------------------------- - Too many RPG Maker assets - Although good combat can sometimes feel awkward and choppy - Music...Just kidding the music kicks ♥♥♥! -------------------------  Tl;Dr: Its an amazing game. It's free so I wasn't expecting much, but I was blown away by just how awesome it is! Being that it's free and no microtransactions exist this is clearly a passion project and I recommend everyone at least tries it!

I play a lot of RPGMaker-type games and it is nice to see an Action RPG for once. This free game is better than many I've paid for. As a poverty gamer, Eternal Senia caught my eyes.   First thing I noticed right after I clicked 'START' is that Senia's sprite is pretty flat and ugly. The illustration is decent but a lot of the visuals left a bit of a bad impression. I messed with the menu screen a bit and the volume slider is much appreciated and the brightness control is a neat bonus. Then I walked through the corridors filled with enemies the player needs to bump into to kill. Fun! No, it was bland and by the third room or so I started rationalizing 'it's free after all'.   Some things happened and there was a cutscene and it signalled to me that the creator was trying after all. Then I met the first boss; then it got angry. At that point, a switch in my head was flipped.   From then on, I went through this game thinking how rather thoughtfully designed it is. A lot of the enemies have some neat gimmick, albeit same-y. The (large) boss fights are fun and they have 'unique' visuals. The skills are all awesome. The maps almost always have something to make it more interesting (i.e. puzzles, etc).  The upgrade system (skill enhancement and crafting plus bonuses) is more of a hodgepodge. But as imperfect as it is, half of it requires the player to pretty much just play the game while the other half, although a bit of a chore, makes for relatively fun games within the game.  I have only one actual complaint about this. It doesn't let the player go back to the previous areas, or if it does, it should make it more obvious. Nothing much is lost though, even if the player missed something, they're just a few stats upgrade and equipment that is quickly outclassed. If the player missed too much though, I'm pretty sure the best weapon and armor are locked out.  Finally, the story--it's decent. It is based on miscommunication and 'misaligned' expectations and whatnot. So people who doesn't like that, take note. The characters aren't too compelling for me but I'm sure they are relatable to enough people.
